desc: The driver steps out of a black sedan that officers have apparently hit with a pepper ball. He tells the officers repeatedly that there is a pregnant woman inside. Officers tell him to leave; he says "fuck you, I ain't going nowhere" and then "Fuck you! Shoot it again!" Officers shoot the car several more times.

title: Police fire teargas canisters and projectiles into peaceful crowd of unarmed protesters
desc: Police fire teargas cannisters into peaceful crowd of unarmed protesters.  Amongst the chaos you can hear the popping sounds of police firing projectiles.

title: Reporter shot with rubber bullets
desc: A reporter for Primer Impacto was livestreaming a protest on Facebook. Around 12 minutes into the video, shots are fired without warning and the woman screams. She says to a man on her crew (in Spanish), "They just hit me, Patricio, in the leg."

title: Police tear gas peaceful protest, including worshipping congregation
desc:
On Sunday May 31st at Monument Circle in Indianapolis, police state they, prior to curfew, were attempting to apprehend a man who allegedly was trying to spray-paint a statue.

To do so, police tear-gassed the entire group gathered, which included 50 members of Liberty Tabernacle, who had gathered to sing, pray and listen to speakers. A tear-gas canister landed at the feet of one member of the congregation who uses a wheelchair.

At a news conference on June 1st, the Police chief stated: "My sincere apologies for anyone who was in this peaceful demonstration downtown that was impacted by the tear gas."

title: Police fire gas at peaceful protesters across active street
desc: Footage shows police and peaceful protesters on opposite sides of an active street. As some protesters step into the street, police fire gas. The filmer states it is tear gas, but a comment states that it is smoke. Regardless, police catch multiple bystander cars in the gas, forcing them to move.

title: LAPD SUV drives into protesters, speeds away
desc: LAPD officer quickly drives his SUV into a crowd near Pershing Square, hitting what looks like two protesters, then throws it in reverse and speeds away

title: Police arrest protesters leaving scene
desc: A crowd gathers around a woman who is being arrested. After she is pulled away, police give a dispersal order. Protesters comply, but appear to exchange words with officers while walking away. Police then shout that they are under arrest, shoving protesters to the ground and kneeling on them to make arrests.

title: Violent arrests made at entrance to Hugh Carey Tunnel
desc: In an incident outside the Hugh Carey Tunnel (West and Morris Streets in Manhattan), police are seen kneeling on a protester to arrest them. The filmer walks down the street, following the advancing police line. An NYPD official wearing a jacket bearing the word "LEGAL," throws a protester's skateboard off the road. The filmer then captures several officers pinning down a protester to arrest them. An officer stands and strikes the protester with his baton repeatedly.

title: Police officer maces woman and kicks her in the head
desc: The individual was sitting on the ground peacefully, yet the police maced her, and since she didn't move, they kicked her in the head.

title: Police shoot rubber bullets at protesters
desc: After a driver forces their way through a crowd, the police start shooting rubber bullets at the people nearby.

title: Man shot in the head with deterrent rounds, is sent to hospital
desc: Man receives a shot to head from what looks to be a large deterrent round, he claims police shot him and he now has internal bleeding in the head. The LAPD has released body cam footage confirming he was shot in the head with a bean bag round while his hands were up. The LAPD says it is investigating the incident.

title: Reporter shows tear gas canister fired at him by police
desc: A reporter posted a picture of a tear gas canister, allegedly used in Lincoln protests. In the tweet, he states he and his photographer were tear gassed twice by police.

title: Police mace, shoot pepper bullets at protesters sitting on the ground
desc: A bunch of protesters peacefully sitting on the ground were shot at and maced. A group of police officers pushed these civilians on to the ground and hit them.

Police pepper spray protesters walking away and later arrest one of them
Riot police fire on protesters without provocation
desc: Officers fire tear gas, rubber bullets and pepper spray BBs at peaceful protesters without warning. Police continue firing as protesters flee.

title: Riot police throw protester to the ground
desc:
A reporter following the protest shows video of the riot police line moving to force protesters back. Then notes that during this, a teenage girl is grabbed, thrown to the ground and surrounded.

On video, protesters can be heard yelling "You feel big hitting a little woman like that?"

An additional angle provided by the girl's sister shows numerous officers lifting her off the ground and dragging her behind the police line, after which the line closes to obfuscate any view of her.

title: Couple pepper-sprayed; woman knocked unconscious; man blinded by rubber bullet
Protester grabbed by hair
Police beat protesters leaving Stonewall Inn solidarity protest
Police fire tear gas down empty streets
desc: An officer mounted atop a personnel carrier fires several tear gas rounds down an empty street without apparent justification

title: Police kettle and fire on fleeing protesters
desc: Police block off sidewalks to kettle protesters outside the Edward J. Schwartz federal building in downtown San Diego. Tear gas canisters can be heard as the police line advances. An officer fires on several fleeing protesters at close range. Protesters are shoved by authorities as they plead for officers to stop firing on them.

title: Police fire rubber/pepper bullets at peaceful protesters
desc: The chants of "don't shoot" are very clear, and at around 0:20, the police opens fire on the peaceful protesters, scattering them.

title: Sheriffs tear gas crowd after accidental vandalism
desc:
Footage from the first link shows two protesters attempting to remove a sign strung between two lampposts on a mezzanine. The lampposts fall over during this process. Then at 00:40, officers rush out of the building, seizing protesters.

The second clip shows officers with rifles making arrests on the mezzanine. Officers then pull what appear to be service pistols and point them at protesters. More officers step out of the building onto the mezzanine and take the staircase. Protesters and police face each other at the foot of the stairs. Protesters begin chanting.

The third clip shows police dropping tear gas canisters from the mezzanine. Protesters flee.

The fourth clip shows protesters attempt to recover their belongings while police launch more tear gas. Protesters flee to the far sidewalk as police move into the street.

An article from the Chattanoogan states Sheriffs threw the tear gas, not Chattanooga police.

title: Police beat kneeling protesters
desc: Protesters kneeling in the street are approached by a line of police in riot gear. Police beat them with their shields, shove them, and appear to be arresting them when a riot round is fired and the camera moves.

title: Police pepper sprays peaceful protester and fires tear gas on crowd
desc: Police officer snatches away protester's sign and and sprays them with pepper spray. They soon begin firing tear gas on the crowd.

title: Journalist injured by tear gas, less-than-lethal round

Woman bleeding from face after being shot by police
desc: After a protester threw a firework at police, police shot tear gas and impact munitions. A journalist livestreaming the incident shows a woman bleeding from the face after being shot by police. She states she was shot by a rubber bullet.

title: Officers grabs someone by the neck then more cops pile on
desc: Protesters arrested as they're leaving, including one grabbed by the neck by city mayor, Bob O'Dekirk, and dogpiled by at least 3 police officers.

Law enforcement push and shove a crowd of protesters.

Police use tear gas to clear road
Student journalist shot and tear gassed
Multiple police officers assault woman
Police pepper spray young child
Police pull off protesters mask to pepper spray him
Police shoot fleeing man at short range
Law enforcement arrest people walking, you can hear on the radio You should not be driving past anybody, stop and take somebody into custody.
desc: Law enforcement arrest people walking, you can hear on the radio You should not be driving past anybody, stop and take somebody into custody, seemingly indiscriminately making arrests even as people are walking and it still looks to be light outside.

title: Police use LRAD, tear gas and pepper spray to dispers protesters
desc:
After declaring a protest an unlawful assembly, police push protesters down the street, continuing to give dispersal order. A single firework is shot off by protesters. At 5:30, police use the LRAD dispersal function. Once again at 7:00.

Around 8:00, police advance, firing tear gas canisters at protesters. Multiple bystander vehicles appear to be caught in the gas. Around 9:50, an officer appears to reach out of a squad car and pepper spray protesters, but the sirens make it difficult to see.

title: Tear gas fired at peaceful protest
desc: Tear gas canisters were launched by police at peaceful protesters around Robert E. Lee Monument at approximately 7:35 PM. The police chief has said that the officers' actions were "unwarranted" and "outside dept protocols." At least one protester has sued the officers involved.

title: Fargo deputy police chief instigates unrest during protest
desc:
In an email sent to the Fargo PD, the deputy chief of police, Todd Osmundson, apologized for instigating unrest during George Floyd protests. He admits to carrying alcoholic containers and to cursing at police officers.

At this protest, individuals were charged with inciting a riot; Osmundson was not one of those individuals despite his unruly presence and aggressive remarks.

Earlier that day, Osmundson appeared in uniform at protests, carrying a supportive sign.

title: Police pepper spray two kneeling protesters
desc:
Two protesters kneel with their hands up 5-10 feet from police. One of the protesters appears to try to talk to the police. Police then pepper-spray the protesters, who then flee.

Users on Twitter allege the woman was a medic attempting to notify the police and/or provide aid to an injured person in a nearby parking garage.

Footage was posted on Twitter as a reply to footage of another incident on June 1st.

title: Police officer pepper-sprays three people on their knees
desc: Three protesters kneeling on the ground with their hands on their heads/covering their faces are pepper-sprayed directly in the face by a cop.

title: Police fire into backs of protesters
Los Angeles law enforcement shoot at a man on his own balcony
desc: Los Angeles police fire less lethal projectiles at several residents of the Ava and Wakaba apartments in Little Tokyo. All of the residents were filming quietly from their balconies.

title: Police officer hides badge number and name
Police shove a woman down to her knees
Police beat kneeling protesters
NYPD denies 6th amendment rights to protesters

Police shoot at, threaten to arrest reporter

Police officer pulls protester to the ground unprovoked
Officer incites violence on social media
desc:
In a since-deleted post on Instagram featuring 3 DPD officers in riot gear, the poster captioned the image: "Let's start a riot."

The officer has since been fired from the Denver Police Department.

title: Police injure sleeping homeless man with flashbang
desc:
Police flashbang hits a homeless man sleeping in a park.

Related to OPD Case 2020OPA-0335 "Homeless man hit by an SPD flashbang while sleeping".

title: Law enforcement break a car window for no apparent reason
desc: A line of law enforcement officers are walking down the street.  When they approach a parked vehicle, law enforcement break the vehicle's window for no apparent reason.

title: Police fire rubber bullet on peaceful protester
desc: Without warning, police shoot protester with rubber bullet. Protester falls limp to the ground. Later image shows the protester helped to their feet and able to walk away

title: Restaurant owner shot and killed
desc: LMPD and KY National Guard were sent to 26th and Broadway to disperse a gathering (unrelated to protests) in violation of curfew. Police officer Katie Crews crosses the street and begins firing pepper balls at a group standing outside. A pepper ball hit the doorway of YaYa's BBQ (the victim's business), nearly striking his niece. He went outside and appears to fire a single shot into the air. He steps inside and then steps back out and is shot and killed by police and guardsman. Officers were required to wear bodycams and have them activated as a reform after the police killing of Breonna Taylor, but of the 20 officers on scene, LMPD claims 0 were using their bodycams.

title: CPD chase down protester on TV
desc: Police chase protester and attack him on the ground while on live TV.

title: Officer threatens protesters with what appears to be a handgun
desc: Officer is seen at 12th and Broadway brandishing what appears to be a handgun and pointing it at protesters.

title: Police pepper spray Des Moines Register reporter even as she repeatedly announced herself as press
desc: Reporter shouts "I'm press! I'm press! I'm going! I'm with the Des Moines Register" repeatedly as she tries to walk away from police. An officer quickly approaches her and pepper sprays her in the eye.

title: Police appear to tear-gas a homeless camp
Tear gas fired across active street at protesters
Journalist injured by tear gas, less-than-lethal round
desc:
Journalist Alex Burness was hit by some sort of projectile. Later in the night, an officer ordered Burness to turn around and walk in the opposite direction (toward a large cloud of tear gas). He shouted "press," but the officer raised his weapon, forcing Burness (and an associate in a neon "press" vest) to walk into the tear gas. Journalist Dave Sachs claims something similar happened to him -- he showed his press pass to police but they shoved him into tear gas.

Burness states that he was gassed on Clarkson st near the Good Times restaurant (808 E Colfax).

title: Law enforcement shoot a woman in the head
Peaceful protesters kneeling are shot with an explosive projectile.
Journalist arrested for curfew violation

Police officer puts his knee on a protesters neck, is pulled off
Police pepper spray sitting protesters
Tattoo artist arrested while painting the outside of his shop; police fail to deescalate
NBC News reporter shot on air
Police strike man with motorcycle
Minnesota state patrol fire tear gas and impact munitions at press
Police open fire on protesters
Police pepper spray and assault protesters
Police injure journalist

Reporter shows tear gas canister fired at him by police
Numerous eyewitness report being tackled by police officers
desc:
Eyewitness reports seeing her boyfriend punched by police officers.

Eyewitness reports seeing numerous people tackled.

Eyewitness reports being slammed from behind after obeying police order to raise hands and disperse. He and his sister report police kneeled on the man's neck "in the same manner as George Floyd."

All three events took place on Main St, at least one of which was near the Main Street Dunkin'.

title: Officer shoots projectile from moving vehicle
desc:
An officer shoots a projectile out of a moving vehicle, striking pedestrian near eyeball.

This incident took place at in Eugene, OR. Specific area not identified.

title: Louisville police swarm and beat a man screaming on the ground
desc: A man was using a leafblower to clear tear-gas from the protest area. Police claimed, without evidence, that the leafblower was "filled with bleach" to injure police.

title: Police pepper spray protesters on their knees
desc: Protesters are seen in the middle of the road on their knees with their hands up. Officers are seen walking on the median and indiscriminately pepper spraying the protesters below them.

title: Officer spits on detained protester
desc: A police officer spits on a detained protester who is restrained and sitting on the ground. The officer appears to repeat the action after other protesters mention that he's on camera. Extended footage shows the officer continuing to spit on the protester.

title: Police fire tear gas and rubber bullets on peaceful assembly
desc: Police declare a peaceful protest an unlawful assembly. They then escalate the situation by firing tear gas and rubber bullets on the crowd.

title: Woman struck in finger by projectile; police quell crowd with tear gas
desc: A crowd of protesters is chanting peacefully. A shot is fired offscreen and a woman screams. Footage shows the woman clutching her bleeding hand. The caption states her finger was "cut off." The crowd becomes agitated and police respond with tear gas.

title: Police choke man and push woman filming event to the ground
desc: Two to three police officers choke a black man on the ground. The woman documenting this on video is then pushed away/over.

title: Cop suddenly punches activist
Business owner flags down police for protection from looters; she is arrested
desc:
Alleged looters and the owner and employees at a liquor store stood off outside store. A crowd had assembled to help the employees. Seeing a police cruiser passing by, one black employee flagged down the officers to request help.

The employee was arrested, along with her husband and others helping them, while the alleged looters ran off. The employee says she told police they had the wrong people and the criminals were getting away. She says the officer arresting her said, "I don't care about them." In addition, she says she was thrown against a wall when arrested.

title: Police selectively enforce curfew and dispersal orders
desc:
During protests, groups of men armed with guns, bats, and other blunt instruments roved around the Fishtown neighborhood of Philadelphia. They continued patrolling after curfew. Footage shows Philadelphia police warning militia to leave so they could enforce arrests of BLM protesters. In addition, images show police chatting and taking photos with the groups. One video taken by a gunman states that the police want to take pictures with them.

Footage shows members of the groups threatening and shouting racial and homophobic slurs at protesters without police intervention. One journalist posted a picture of himself with a head wound, alleging that one of these groups beat him for filming them.

title: Police strike active news crew with tear gas
desc: Police strike a journalist, Jo-Ling Kent, live on air with a tear gas canister.

title: Officer pepper-sprays a woman who is on her knees with her hands up
desc: A woman in East Liberty gets onto her knees and puts her hands in the air, while repeatedly yelling "we're peaceful, don't shoot!" Officers approach her and one of them sprays pepper spray onto her. The woman who recorded the video, Abigail Rubio, claims the police returned the next day and claimed they had video evidence of her throwing items off her balcony at them, a claim she denies and says was meant to intimidate her after posting the video. She filed a complaint with the local Citizen Review Board

title: Pastor violently arrested during protest
desc:
During a protest on June 1st, a pastor was arrested. He states officers yelled at him and told him to move. When he did not, he states that an officer ordered others to arrest him; those officers then threw him to the ground to handcuff him.

Footage from news sources show 2 officers kneeling on his legs and back. It also shows an officer pressing what appears to be a service sidearm to the pastor's head. One news sourcee and the pastor's official complaint state this occurred on Shelbyville Road in front of the Oxmoor Center mall.

After Findley was placed in a squad car, he told police he was a pastor. He was then released without charges.

The pastor is now suing the Louisville Metropolitan Police Department.

title: Officer pepper sprays passerby
desc: Footage taken at 41 E 57th St in Manhattan shows an officer running down the street. He pepper sprays several bystanders as he runs past them.

title: Police fire tear gas at prone protesters
desc: A group of protesters lie on the ground with arms outstretched in front of a ground of police.  Police approach, then fire three pepper balls and a gas canister at protesters from close range.

title: Police push and tackle man that is being vocal
desc: Police seemingly single out a person that is being the most vocal, push and tackle him to the ground despite him not resisting.

title: Police push and pepper spray reporters from The Lantern newspaper
desc:
Location: Starbucks at the intersection of Lane Avenue and North High Street

Three reporters repeatedly tell police that they are members of the press and show their passes. Reporters are exempt from curfew but the police instruct them to leave regardless, then spray the Lantern reporters with pepper spray.

title: Police arrest man using excessive force, dogs
desc: Police threw tear gas at protesters blocking a roadway in an effort to disperse them. One protester, Joseph Malott, allegedly threw a tear gas canister back at police. Police arrested him for (per Mercury News) assaulting a police officer with a deadly weapon. During the arrest, Malott was bitten and scratched repeatedly by a police dog, leaving bite marks and scratches all over his back and a wound on his leg which required 10 stitches. During the arrest, he says he was slammed against a fence then thrown to the ground, and recalls thinking when are they going to take the dogs off me?

title: Officer fires tear gas canister at protester's head
desc: DCPD officer aims tear gas canister at protester's head, narrowly misses.

title: Journalist shows alleged rubber bulet injury
desc: A journalist shows a wound on his leg consistent with injuries from a non-lethal round. Forensic Architecture has stated he was hit with a rubber bullet.

title: Reporter struck with shield and baton
desc: As a reporter tries to let the police pass by him, they pin him to the wall with a shield and an officer hits his knee with a baton.

title: Police arrest protesters en masse and detain them in poor conditions
Journalist detained by police near downtown connector
Officer shoots projectile from moving vehicle
Philadelphia Police Trap Protesters on Highway, Then Tear Gas Them and Shoot Rubber Bullets
Police fire tear gas and rubber bullets on peaceful assembly
Numerous eyewitness report being tackled by police officers
Police arrest reporter and force him to ground, grab another reporter
Police arrest woman and reporter
Officer spits on detained protester
Police shove protesters and strike man across the face with a baton
desc:
Police shove a group of protesters. A particularly aggressive police officer in a white shirt runs and shoves someone, then grabs another man. He is then approached by a young man with long hair whom he strikes with his baton, at full strength, in the head before jumping on him and cuffing him. He has assistance from another officer who presses the man's face to the pavement using his knee on his neck. Twitter accounts misreport the individual as female; later accounts in media report the individual is a male Temple University engineering student.

He now faces charges of aggravated assault, simple assault, possession of an instrument of crime and recklessly endangering another person. His bail was set at $10,000. The officer has been suspended with intent to dismiss him. The protester was detained for 24 hours, but ultimately released without charges.

title: Police fire tear gas at peaceful protest
desc:
During a peaceful protest on Broad Street near University of Georgia (UGA), police began firing tear gas indiscriminately and with excess.

One protester can be seen with a firework, similar to a Roman candle, firing from considerable distance and into the air.

Police fired a sustained barrage of tear gas for approximately one minute while protesters retreated.

Later footage shows police continuing to fire tear gas down the street as students walk past with their hands up, obeying police orders.

title: Police fire at protesters on ground
desc: Protesters laid on ground and chanted. Police may have given dispersal order, but it is difficult to hear. Within 10 seconds of audible order, as protesters began standing, police fired projectiles at protesters. Police continued to fire off and on for at least one minute while protesters obeyed order to retreat.

title: Police arrest protester then tear gas crowd
desc:
Footage shows police officers around several protest-related arrestees. A woman argues with them at a distance. Police then approach her and arrest her. They force her to a seated position on the ground. They then lift her and place her face down on the ground.

The crowd begins to object and asks why she is being arrested. Another officer then releases a tear gas canister and throws it at the crowd.

title: Police use tear gas on protesters peacefully blocking road
desc: Police tell protesters blocking road to disperse and then immediately use tear gas on them.

title: Police arrest woman and reporter
desc:
Footage shows a woman tackled by multiple officers and thrown into bushes before an officer kneels on her to make an arrest. Another protester is arrested in the background.

As reporter is backing away, police yell at him to go him.

Another officer is heard saying, "Fuck him," before arresting the reporter.

title: Police jump out of car to shove protesters
desc: A police vehicle stops at an intersection; protesters are gathered on the sidewalk nearby. Several officers jump out of the car and rush onto the sidewalk, shoving and chasing protesters.

title: Law enforcement fire on crowd with their arms up chanting
desc: Protesters standing with their arms raised are chanting "This is what democracy looks like".  Law enforcement fire on the crowd and gas can be seen.

title: Police fire at protesters on ground
Australian news crew and protesters attacked by police
desc: Protesters and an Australian reporter and cameraman were attacked by police while reporting on protests in DC. An officer charged directly at the journalist and appeared to punch her. The journalist identified herself at media, and identified that tear gas and rubber bullets were used.

title: Police shove bicyclist to the ground
Police pepper spray two kneeling protesters
Restaurant owner shot and killed
Fargo deputy police chief instigates unrest during protest
Police selectively enforce curfew and dispersal orders
Riot police fire on protesters without provocation
Police tear gas peaceful protest
Alleged looter pulled from car and beaten
Journalist shows alleged rubber bulet injury
Officer fires tear gas canister at protester's head
Reporter struck with shield and baton
Police strike active news crew with tear gas
Journalist shoved by police
Police jump out of car to shove protesters
Police shove protesters on the sidewalk
Protesters fleeing tear gas are pepper-sprayed and struck when they ask police where they are supposed to go
desc:
Protesters flee from tear gas and attempt to follow police dispersal order. As they turn a corner, they are met by more officers. They ask these officers where to go, stating they just want to go home.

The officers gesture with batons. One officer pepper-sprays a protester. A second strikes the filmer with his baton. A third kicks a tear gas canister at protesters.

title: Police use excessive force during an arrest
Police pepper spray protesters during arrest
desc: During a protest in Orlando, at the intersection of W South St. and S Division Ave, police tackle a protester and arrest them. The crowd becomes agitated and gathers around. Police pepper spray protesters, including one man in a wheelchair, who then has difficulty leaving the scene. Protesters then rush to aid the man in the wheelchair.

title: Police casually pepper spray passers by
desc: Two squad cars full of police arrive at an intersection, sirens wailing. Police get out and start pepper-spraying people. Notably, there are two people on a fire escape who look like they may be treating two others for pepper-spray or tear gas exposure. Police pepper-spray them. Police later pepper spray one a second time, as she's in the process of retreating and rinsing her eyes with milk due to the first pepper spray exposure.

title: Police violence outside the White House
desc: MSNBC captures mounted and regular police using flashbangs on peaceful protesters outside the White House. Someone injured by police is carried away live on camera.

title: Peaceful protesters arrested for breaking curfew
desc:
Omaha law enforcement officer kicks protester already on the ground. Another officer carries a reporter away from the scene.

Twitter users also state police fired pepper-balls at peaceful protesters.

title: Man who sheltered protesters discusses law enforcement officers shooting tear gas into his house
desc: A DC resident discusses being accosted by officers when trying to enter his home. Once inside, a crowd of protesters were allegedly confined to the street by officers, at which point the resident offered to shelter them in his home. He claims that officers then fired tear gas into his home.

title: Police tackle & pepper spray peaceful protesters
desc: Footage shows police charging at protesters and tackling one to the ground. Several officers join to support. The crowd becomes agitated. Police release the tackled individual, then pepper-spray him and another peaceful protester. Police continue to discharge pepper spray and force away protesters trying to aid victims.

title: Police arrest man using excessive force, dogs
Multiple cops pin man to ground while repeatedly punching him
Pastor violently arrested during protest
Police use LRAD, tear gas and pepper spray to dispers protesters
Police pepper spray protesters on their knees
Video showing CPD officer punching protester in Uptown under investigation
Police push and pepper spray reporters from The Lantern newspaper
Australian news crew and protesters attacked by police
Police charge peaceful crowd, beat them with shields
Protester falls and is stepped on
Law enforcement fire on crowd with their arms up chanting
Police throw explosives at protesters
Tear gas fired at peaceful protest
Police surround approved medical station and destroy supplies
desc:
Police destroy supplies, including food and water, at a medical station. Medics and EMTs said the station was approved by the city.

Additional investigation found the station was on private property and conducted with approval from the property owner.

title: Police shoot tear gas/flashbang grenade into a crowd
desc: Police shoot about a dozen tear gas or flashbang grenades into a crowd from quite a distance.

title: Law enforcement gas teenagers at a park
desc: Law enforcement disrupt teenagers' peaceful protest by throwing a gas grenade and almost starting a fire.

title: Unmarked federal agents aid police
Police fire tear gas at peaceful protesters
desc: A small number of peaceful protesters are scattered in the street. Someone shouts, "Get back," and protesters begin running. Shots can be heard and tear gas is fired into the crowd.

title: Protester grabbed by hair
desc: In an incident at 17 Battery Place in Manhattan, police are forcibly arresting several protesters on a paved pedestrian area. A protester argues with an officer. The officer shoves her and grabs her by the hair. Another officer joins in; the two grab her by the arms, force her to the ground, and one officer kneels on the protester to arrest her.

title: Police beat protesters leaving Stonewall Inn solidarity protest
desc: Police beat protesters leaving Stonewall Inn after a demonstration honoring queer and people of color who died at hands of police, in solidarity with George Floyd. One man had his arm broken and required multiple staples to close wounds on his head.

title: NYPD officers beat woman
desc: A woman is walking on the sidewalk with a peaceful protest near the China Institute. Officers walk beside her. She turns to see them and an officer strikes her in the face. Other officers then pull her from the protest and surround her to make an arrest.

title: Police fire into a crowd of peaceful protesters at short range
Police retaliate to thrown water bottle with excessive force
Police throw explosives at protesters
desc: Police declare unlawful assembly on a small, peaceful protest outside of police station a little bit before midnight. The police officer informs that they have 3 to 5 minutes to leave. In less than 3 minutes the police come out of their building and throw explosives at protesters. The explosives appear to be stun grenades.

title: Police pull away protester and pepper sprays others
desc: A police officer pulls away a protester standing still. When others come to the protester's aid they are pepper sprayed.

title: Journalist shoved by police
desc: A 60-year-old photographer working for Syracuse.com/The Post Standard was shoved by police while filming a protest in front of the Public Safety Building on South Street. He was wearing a company-issued identification card and had two cameras slung on his shoulders. He was knocked to the ground, and two camera lenses were broken in the process.

title: Armored law enforcement vehicle threatens protesters, deploys tear gas on highway
desc: In this video, an armored law enforcement vehicle tells protesters blocking a highway to disperse over megaphone. It sounds like the operator is saying "if you do not move, you will be dead," but video later released by the police department seems to show that the operator instead said "if you do not move, you will be gassed." The protesters do not move; the officers deploy tear gas, coating the highway in dense, opaque clouds of blinding fog. Vehicles are seen waiting to continue on their way; it is unclear whether these vehicles attempted to navigate the clouds of tear gas. (Note: Jalopnik reports that this happened on June 2; however, protests consistent with the video were only reported on June 1, and other sources place the video on June 1.)

title: Video showing CPD officer punching protester in Uptown under investigation
desc: CPD officer chasing down and punching a protester who was walking away.

title: Police fatally shoot unarmed 22 year old
Police fire tear gas at peaceful protest
Law enforcement arrest people walking, you can hear on the radio You should not be driving past anybody, stop and take somebody into custody.
Police shove protesters and strike man across the face with a baton
Police arrest protester then tear gas crowd
Police officer pepper-sprays three people on their knees
Police casually pepper spray passers by
Police pepper spray Des Moines Register reporter even as she repeatedly announced herself as press
Police violence outside the White House
Student journalist struck by ricocheting foam bullet
Police pepper spray crowd
Police pepper spray protesters during arrest
Police tackle man giving interview
Police shoot man in groin with rubber bullet
desc: An officer rips a sign away from a protester then shoots him in the groin with a rubber bullet at close range. The protester suffered serious injuries to his testicles and was rushed to an emergency room.

title: Police push protester on bike, slap phone out of his hand
desc: Footage shows a protester on a bicycle who was blocking the street. As he is moving out of the way, police continue to push him on the side, hindering his balance. One officer slaps his phone out of his hand.

title: Police use or threaten to use pepper-spray in an elevator on apartment residents trying to go home
desc: Police use or threaten to use pepper-spray in what appears to be a private residence apartment elevator. The people keep saying things like "we are just trying to go home" and "we live here". Some get pulled out of the elevator while others leave on their own. It appears they are all being arrested as the video ends.

title: Police fire into backs of protesters
desc: A handful of protesters are seen walking away from police with their hands up. Police shoot at the protesters repeatedly for the duration of the video, about 40 seconds.

title: Police shove protesters with bikes
desc:
A woman films a BLM protest in Orlando from a window. Protesters have gather around a police bike line blocking an intersection. Police begin shouting and shove protesters back with their bikes.

The incident appears to have occurred near Orlando City Hall.

title: Officers deploy tear gas against peaceful protesters
desc: Police deploy tear gas against protesters after drunk driver ran into oncoming traffic, knocking over a woman and child. Police arrested the driver. Police said some protesters thought police were arresting a protester and attempted to intervene; the Lewisville mayor stated that police deployed tear gas because protesters were blocking a road. Police then deployed tear gas against the crowd and arrested 9 protesters. After tear gas was deployed, police allege that protesters threw bottles at officers.

title: Police beat protester with batons, then pepper spray another man for recording
desc: Police isolate protester and then 4 to 5 officers beat him with a baton.  When one of them realizes he is being recorded, he pepper sprays the person recording to make him stop.

title: Police maneuver protesters onto bridge and fire tear gas and rubber bullets
desc: On June 2nd, protesters are routed onto Margaret Hunt Hill Bridge. They are met by a line of police officers and are then fired upon by rubber bullets, tear gas, and more.

title: Alleged looter pulled from car and beaten
desc:
Footage shows a cluster of NYPD officers striking a vehicle with batons and kicking it, before pulling the driver onto the street and arresting them. Footage shows police smashed several of the car's windows.

Officers allege the driver and passenger were looters and had tried to run over police.

Officers additionally allege that the passenger attempted to jump to the driver's seat, run over an NYPD officer, and drive away. However, footage shows heavy traffic on all sides of the car and does not capture the alleged attempt by the passenger.

The driver was charged with attempted murder, assault with intent to cause injury, criminal possession of stolen property, and obstructing government administration. The DA's office later downgraded the attempted murder charge to second-degree assault.

title: Police arrest reporter and force him to ground, grab another reporter
desc: Video shows multiple police seizing a reporter and forcing him to the ground. The source claims he was grabbed by his bandana and pulled into multiple officers as well.

title: Police charge peaceful crowd, beat them with shields
desc: Here, police are captured charging into a crowd of peaceful protesters and hitting them with their shields. One individual can be seen bleeding from the mouth after being struck, before being pushed to the ground.

title: Armored law enforcement vehicle threatens protesters, deploys tear gas on highway
Police shoot rubber bullets at two peaceful protesters
Louisville police swarm and beat a man screaming on the ground
Police fire rubber bullet on peaceful protester
Officer attacks woman for no apparent reason
Riot police throw protester to the ground
CPD chase down protester on TV
Law enforcement tear-gas a crowd chanting we want peace right after exiting the building.
Police pull away protester and pepper sprays others
Man who sheltered protesters discusses law enforcement officers shooting tear gas into his house
Police tackle & pepper spray peaceful protesters
Police grab protester and throw into brick wall
Police on bikes restrain man using knee on neck
desc: Protesters were congregating at the intersection of North 6th Street and McKinley Avenue. A group of officers on bikes rode up to them. Two officers on bikes collided with one another; one officer fell to the ground. Officers then tackled a protester (for reasons unknown) and attempted to take him into custody, with one officer placing a knee on his neck or head for one or two minutes. No officers intervened to get the knee off the man's neck; police formed a barrier to screen the arrest from other protesters and people filming. At the same time, police arrested one other man and hit a woman in the collarbone -- again, for reasons unknown. The man who had an officer's knee on his neck has sued.

title: Tear gas fired across active street at protesters
desc:
In events occurring either late on June 2nd or in the early morning of June 3rd, police can be heard declaring unlawful assembly and seen firing tear gas across the street at gathered protesters. Some protesters appear to throw tear gas canisters back.

There are numerous passing cars that appear unrelated to the protest but are caught in the gas. They struggle to maneuver around canisters & clouds of tear gas.

title: Police launch tear gas into a crowd
desc: Police deploy flashbangs and tear gas into a crowd.

title: Officer refuses to give diabetic arrestee her insulin back
desc: Protesters are trying to leave at curfew and are offered a ride. They get into a car. One woman identfies that she is diabetic and needs her insulin. Police make them exit the vehicle. We then see the protesters sitting on the ground surrounded by police. The woman again explains to an officer that she needs her insulin from her bag as she is diabetic. The officer refuses.

title: Police charge protesters and press
desc:
Police line is seen using shields to push back a small group of protesters. The filmer, a reporter, moves around to the other side of the protesters. At this point, the footage captures another group of police officers charging the protesters from behind without warning.

The footage becomes blurry as it appears that police strike the reporter, who repeatedly states, "I am press," and is standing alongside several camera crews.

The reporter states that they were beaten by police, their glasses were broken, and their phone thrown. In a subsequent video, the reporter speaks to the police chief and states in the description that they were pepper-sprayed. The police chief states that he will open an investigation. A second reporter off-screen tells the chief that multiple journalists were assaulted. One journalist was briefly arrested and zip-tied before being released.

title: Police fire on protesters without warning
desc: Police are protesters are gathered several feet apart. Between the two lines, a protester is seen telling other protesters to put their hands up. Police then fire as protesters scatter. A journalist was also shot in the leg.

title: Protester beaten with baton
desc: Footage taken at West and Rector Streets in Manhattan shows a protester in the road with a bike. An officer attempts to take it, but the protester holds on. The officer then uses his baton to press against the protester's neck before striking the protester in the legs. Other officers join to separate the protester from their bike.

title: Violent arrests made in Grant Park
Police fire into crowd hitting one protester
Officer threatens protesters with what appears to be a handgun
Police injure sleeping homeless man with flashbang
Reporters shot by pepper balls on air
Police choke man and push woman filming event to the ground
Officer strikes peaceful crowd with baton, police then fire riot rounds
desc:
Footage shows police near a group of protesters. One officer walks across the line of protesters, shoving many of them with his baton. Another officer then shoves an individual in a wheelchair. A third officer then grabs the wheelchair and pushes that individual away, back behind the police line.

Protesters become agitated and police begin firing riot rounds.

After 50 seconds, footage cuts to various other incidents.

title: Police appear to tear-gas a homeless camp
desc: Actual deployment of tear-gas not shown. Video shows what appears to be a cloud of tear-gas over several tents. The camera thens pans to show 5 cops walking away

title: Police fire into a crowd of peaceful protesters at short range
desc:
Police are shown shoving a wall of peaceful protesters back from an intersection. Shortly after, officers begin to fire rubber bullets at the protesters from close range.

Footage does not indicate that any protesters were violent with any officer before the shooting began.

title: LAPD destroy car to drag out occupants
desc: LAPD seen smashing windows to drag passengers & driver out of a stopped car. The people inside said they were out protesting. So far LAPD hasnt said why the stop was made.

title: Water bottle tossed at police; police retaliate against crowd
desc: Footage shows a water bottle lobbed towards police. Police then retaliate against the entire crowd, firing tear gas indiscriminately.

title: Officers violently arrest protesters on the sidewalk
desc: Footage from an extended stream shows police and protesters facing off on the sidewalk. Protesters are standing still several feet away from police. On multiple occasions, several officers push from the police line, seize protesters without warning and drag them behind police lines for arrest. Only after several minutes does an officer emerge to explain that protesters will be arrested. After this, protesters comply without resistance.

title: Officers beat man with batons
desc: Police are seen on Greene Street in SoHo, beating a man trying to escape, hitting him multiple times with batons, instead of trying to detain him.

title: Police fire on protesters outside city hall
desc:
Police open fire on protesters outside of city hall with tear gas, flashbangs, and apparently rubber bullets.

Additional footage shows the incident was instigated when officers shoved a protester. The protester then fled. Officers tackled another protester on the sidewalk, then began firing riot control rounds.

title: Florissant officer hits man with unmarked police vehicle
desc:
A resident's door bell camera captures a officer running over a man, who is heard screaming "I don't have anything" and attempting to escape after getting hit. The officer kicks the man while he is down once and then hits him again with his forearm.

Later updates note that the victim has taken to the hospital and the officer has been suspended. There is no body cam footage because the officer was not wearing one at the time. There is also no dash-cam footage.

The officer has since been fired.

The incident occurred in Dellwood, Missouri, a small St. Louis County town west of Ferguson and Southwest of Florissant. However, Florissant police confirmed a member of their staff struck the individual.

title: Reporter detained and handcuffed
Protester with bike tackled by police
NYPD officers beat woman
Police use or threaten to use pepper-spray in an elevator on apartment residents trying to go home
Police arrest protesters en masse and detain them in poor conditions
Police shoot unarmed man in a wheelchair in the face
Police shoot man in groin with rubber bullet
Police on bikes restrain man using knee on neck
Police launch tear gas into a crowd
Police shoot tear gas/flashbang grenade into a crowd
Police shove protesters
desc: Footage from Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn shows officers pushing a protest. Several officers are seen shoving protesters.

title: Man walking his bike beaten by officers with batons
desc: At 50th Street and 3rd Avenue, a man crossing the street with his bike at a stoplight crosswalk is beaten by police with batons.

title: Police deployed impact munitions and pepper spray against protesters before mass arrests
desc: Police at a Tampa protest violently dispersed protesters using smoke, impact munitions and pepper spray. A reporter states dozens of protesters were arrested. During this incident, a journalist was arrested and zip tied with her hands behind her back before being released about 15 minutes later.

title: Police officer punches detained protester repeatedly
Law enforcement close on protesters from both sides with pepper bullets, tear gas, and flashbangs
desc:
Law enforcement close on protesters from both sides with pepper bullets, tear gas, and flashbangs. Some protesters escape into an adjacent parking structure.

Jeff Jackson, an NC State senator whose district contains the Uptown Charlotte area, later posted a review of the incident on Medium.com, in which he decries the incident and states he has begun the process of opening an investigation with the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department.

Body cam footage released several months later shows police coordinating the kettling and tear gassing.

title: Police shoot protester from behind with tear gas canister
desc: An activist and member of the Use of Force committee for Denver Police says officers rolled a tear gas canister toward her and shot her in the back with pepper balls as she retreated. She has since resigned from the use of force committee, citing this incident as the reason.

title: Police shoot at and pepper spray protesters and press
desc:
Police advance on protesters without explanation, firing impact munitions and chasing protesters with pepper spray. A journalist reports seeing multiple protesters detained by police.

Two journalists are pepper sprayed by police officers despite standing where they had been directed to, and displaying press credentials.

title: Reporter detained and handcuffed
desc: During an Oakland protest on June 2nd, police charged protesters and began a series of mass arrests. KPIX reporter Katie Nielsen was handcuffed and detained during the incident, though she was soon released. Images of her detention show a clearly visible press pass clipped to her belt loop. She was released several minutes later and issued an apology by a police spokesperson.

title: Water bottle tossed at police; police retaliate against crowd
Police officer tackles and knees man on the ground
desc: Cop in Baytown Texas pulls over a black man. A white man is on the phone talking about it. Cop says white man is cussing in public and proceeds to tackle him and knee him in the head.

title: Police use excessive force during an arrest
desc: A police officer grabs a protester from behind (light grey hoodie), pull him out of the crowd and several police tackle him to the ground. Other officers pepper spray and shove other people in the aftermath.

title: Police collide with woman; she pushes back; police escalate
desc: In an incident at Fourth and Atlantic Avenues in Brooklyn, footage shows police chasing a protester down the sidewalk. Police appear to trip the protester, who falls to the ground. Police then strike and jab him with batons. A white-shirted officer arrives and steps on the protester's neck

title: Police officer tackles protester
Officers beat man with batons
Police assault peaceful protesters
Police shoot at and pepper spray protesters and press
Officers violently arrest protesters on the sidewalk
Police officer tackles and knees man on the ground
Police fire tear gas at peaceful protesters
Police fire tear gas at peaceful protesters
Police tackle injured man leaving protest
Police shoot protester from behind with tear gas canister
Police officer punches detained protester repeatedly
desc: Footage taken at Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn shows several officers detaining a protester. One officer approaches and punches the protester repeatedly.

title: Police using selective enforcement on black individuals
desc: Multiple people pass by the police until they decide to arrest the only two black individuals in the line.

title: Police officer pepper sprays protesters for no reason
desc: Police officer exits his vehicle and begins pepper spraying protesters for no apparent reason.

title: Police tear gas reporters
desc: Police use tear gas on reporters and protesters, who are then initially blocked from leaving the area by other officers.

title: Police SUV accelerates towards protesters
desc:
In helicopter footage from KGW, protesters are seen moving police barricades and traffic cones on the street. It is unclear if protesters are attempting to clear the street or form a barricade.

A police SUV accelerates into the intersection, swerving towards protesters, which forces them to run out of the way.

title: Police shoot small group of unarmed protesters
desc:
Police give orders to disperse and subsequently to lay on the ground. Protesters attempt to flee and first-person footage states a protester was tripped and shot at short range.

Additional footage shows numerous officers corralling protesters into a small area before firing

title: Police strike and shove protesters
desc: Footage from Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn shows officers and protesters meeting. Officers use their batons to shove protesters, including one astride a bike.

title: Police shove a protesting woman down a set of concrete steps.
desc: Police shove a protesting woman down a set of concrete steps.

title: Police deployed impact munitions and pepper spray against protesters before mass arrests
Woman stopped by police while leaving protest; police break her car window
Police officer body slams protester
desc:
A police officer comes from behind a protester, lifts him over shoulder height and then slams him into the road, head first.

Note: major construction was occurring on this date, causing the area to look slightly different.

title: Police fire tear gas at peaceful protesters
desc: A crowd of peaceful protesters downtown refused to disperse upon curfew taking effect. A protester in a tie-die shirt kicked tear gas away from a fellow kneeling protester, and was then arrested by police against a National Guard humvee.

title: Unmarked federal agents aid police
desc: Armed men are seen supporting police efforts. When asked to identify themselves, they stated only that they work for the Department of Justice or "the federal government." They had no identifying names or numbers.

title: Law enforcement gas teenagers at a park
Protester beaten with baton
Officer refuses to give diabetic arrestee her insulin back
Police fire on protesters without warning
LAPD officers fire at passers by out of the window of a patrol car
Officer strikes peaceful crowd with baton, police then fire riot rounds
Protesters fleeing tear gas are pepper-sprayed and struck when they ask police where they are supposed to go
Police shove protesters with bikes
Police push protester on bike, slap phone out of his hand
Motorist honks in support of protest; Police stop her
desc: A motorist driving by the protest honks in support. An NYPD officer approaches her and demands her keys, threatening to arrest her. Protesters intervene and distract the officers so the motorist is able to leave.

title: Police shove their way through a crowd of protesters
desc: Footage from Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn shows protesters lock arms on the sidewalk to protect injured protesters as police approach. Police begin shoving the protesters and striking them with batons, including the injured protester lying on the ground.

title: Police preemptively tear gas peaceful protesters
desc:
A Huntsville PD Lieutenant stated that they used tear gas on protesters before violence occurred, adding that "they weren't going to roll the dice".

Footage taken of a protester in a garage after shows bruises consistent with rubber bullet rounds. Another image shows a bloody wound allegedly caused by a rubber bullet.

title: Police kneel on man who says "I can't breathe", officer yells profanities back
desc: At least 6 officers surround a handcuffed man who says "I can't breathe". Officer replies "Shut up asshole. Are you fucking stupid? Shut up, that shit don't work here."

title: Woman stopped by police while leaving protest; police break her car window
desc:
A woman is in her car leaving a protest near the intersection of Curry Ford Road and Chickasaw Trail. Police stop her, stating she was blocking a roadway. The officer says she can exit the car or be removed. The woman says she doesn't believe she did anything wrong. The officer then reaches inside her window for the lock. He cannot, so the window is broken.

She was released shortly after with minor abrasions and no charges.

title: Officer forces woman into car and wrestles with another
desc: Officer forces woman into cop car and wrestles with another woman on her phone.

title: Police kneel to lure protesters closer before firing
desc: Police feign a show of support by kneeling and draw protesters closer. After protesters kneel, police begin firing tear gas rounds.

title: Police officer pepper sprays protesters for no reason
Police kneel on man who says "I can't breathe", officer yells profanities back
Man walking his bike beaten by officers with batons
Law enforcement officers throw stinger grenades at peaceful protesters
Police shove a protesting woman down a set of concrete steps.
Police shove their way through a crowd of protesters
Police shoot small group of unarmed protesters
Police strike and shove protesters
Sheriff scuffles with protester over "F\*ck Trump" sign
Police arrest a nonviolent Black cyclist at a BLM supply drop-off event
desc: Police arrest a Black cyclist at a BLM supply drop-off event. The cyclist, with a Guy Fawkes mask, stands in the middle of a parking lot as two police officers handcuff him and pull him into their vehicle. After questioning him, they release him saying they got the wrong guy".

title: Officer punches protester repeatedly
desc: Footage from Lee Avenue and Heyward Street in Brooklyn shows police piling on multiple protesters. Notably, one officer punches a protester repeatedly.

title: Police tackle group of peaceful protesters
desc: Denver SWAT unit tackles group of peaceful protesters who were walking and chanting (around 12:20am).

title: Police assault peaceful protesters
desc: In an incident at Fifth Avenue and 83rd st in Manhattan, an officer moves into a crowd of protesters, grabs a protester by the shirt from behind and drags them. When the protester resists and another attempts to help, police tackle the first protester. The second protester is lifted and thrown to the ground.

title: Police use LRAD (sound cannon) to disperse protesters
desc:
Video shows sound cannon deployed alongside APC. The LRAD can be heard with its characteristic alarm.

The use of LRADs is a subject of much contention, with frequent reports of permanent nerve and hearing damage caused by their use.

The ACLU's [position](https://www.aclu.org/fact-sheet/acoustic-weapons-fact-sheet) is that due to the high risk of damage and lack of research on lasting effects, LRADs should not be deployed to disperse protests.

title: Florissant officer hits man with unmarked police vehicle
Officers deploy flashbangs and pepper spray peaceful protesters
Violent arrests made at entrance to Hugh Carey Tunnel
Police cut off protesters on Hoan Bridge
Police maneuver protesters onto bridge and fire tear gas and rubber bullets
Police use LRAD (sound cannon) to disperse protesters
Police fire on protesters outside city hall
LAPD destroy car to drag out occupants
Police surround approved medical station and destroy supplies
Police choke and beat bicyclist
desc: Footage from Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn shows an officer grabbing a protester with a bicycle and choking them before slamming them to the ground and arresting them.

title: Police throw tear-gas at protesters on a bridge.
desc:
Police throw tear-gas at protesters that are on the Crescent City Connection bridge and cannot easily disperse.

Additional images show a protester bleeding after allegedly being struck in the head by a tear gas canister. A Twitter user claiming to be the woman's child says the woman was taken to the hospital for treatment.

title: Police arrest two reporters
desc:
Police arrested two AL.com journalists covering a protest at 7:35 on June 3. There was a 7PM curfew in effect, which exempted journalists who were carrying a letter from their media outlet; both arrested journalists were carrying such a letter and had press lanyards. Both journalists were released shortly thereafter; while in custody, they were photographed. Birmingham police later said that the arrest was made for the journalists' safety.

Two employees of Alabama Media Group were restrained using zip ties.

title: Protester shows wound inflicted by less-lethal round
desc: Footage from June 3rd shows a still of a wound on a protester's abdomen, inflicted by a less-lethal round. This is in the wake of a Mayoral ordinance for the LAPD to restrict their use of kinetic projectiles, particularly rubber bullets, and the injury is more consistent with direct, close range fire than proper use. Footage was taken in Downtown LA. While it is not clear exactly where the shot was fired, the protester states at one point that he was near the harbor freeway entrance in downtown LA.

title: Law enforcement officers fire rubber bullets into crowd, pepper-spray kneeling protester and CNN crew
desc: In the first of these videos, a crowd can be seen shaking a piece of temporary fencing. Either in response to this or to secure the fence, law enforcement officers fire rubber bullets into the crowd to clear them. In the second video and third videos, officers pepper-spray a kneeling protester and a CNN camera crew. The second video ends with more rubber bullets being fired. The reason for this is unknown.

title: Law enforcement officers throw stinger grenades at peaceful protesters
desc: In this video, officer throw stinger grenades in a crowd chanting "black lives matter". Throughout, grenades continue to be used, one of which explodes directly in front of a peaceful protester.

title: Police throw tear-gas at protesters on a bridge.
Protester shows wound inflicted by less-lethal round
Police arrest two reporters
Law enforcement officers fire rubber bullets into crowd, pepper-spray kneeling protester and CNN crew
Police preemptively tear gas peaceful protesters
Police confiscate protester's bike
Police SUV accelerates towards protesters
Police seen without badges
desc: Footage pans over a line of cops, none of whom have badges. The crowd is chanting, "Where's your badges?"

title: Unknown federal agents aid police
desc:
Footage shows a line of agents wearing riot gear. They do not have names, badges or body cams. They allegedly refused to tell protesters what agency sent them.

Additional reports suggest they are members of the federal Bureau of Prisons trained specifically for prison riots.

title: Officer shoves protester
desc: Footage taken at E 136th St and Brook Ave in the Bronx shows protesters confronting police on bikes. A protester steps forward near police and appears to say something. An officer shoves the protester and yells: "Back up."

title: Riot police fire tear gas round at protester
desc: At short range, officer fires a tear gas round directly at a protester. The round narrowly misses striking the protester in the face.

title: Police remove badges
desc: The video shows fficers standing in line, all missing the badges from their uniforms. The video poster, in the comments of the post, states that the officers took off their badges and then pushed protesters down the stairs and swung batons at them.

title: Law enforcement shoot and throw tear gas at protesters
desc: Law enforcement stand off with protesters. Seemingly without provocation they start gassing and shooting at the protesters.

title: Police throw reporter into fire
desc: Policemen throw a reporter to the ground, apparently with little or no warning and possibly toward a fire.

title: Police shoot non-violent protester in the head
desc:
Here, a non-violent protester can be seen standing perfectly still when he is hit directly in the head by a bean bag round and knocked to the floor.

In the aftermath other protesters help the victim who is bleeding from a large head wound. Further reports state the victim was hospitalized

title: Police spray two people who are backing away
desc: A crowd of police officers walk towards two people on the side walk. The two people move away slowly. One of them turns, pointing a phone at the officers; an officer sprays them (probably with mace).

title: Police shoot young woman in the head with a rubber bullet
Police shove and scream at men walking down the street
Photographer tackled to the ground by four police officers
Police tear gas peaceful protesters
Person with hands up struck in chest by projectile
Police shoot unarmed woman in the face with a rubber bullet
Police repeatedly shove protester
Crowd of journalists tear gassed
Woman is charged by police and thrown to the ground
Protester shot in head
Los Angeles law enforcement hit protester in the face with rubber bullet
Cop shoving a person to the ground towards metal trash bins
Continuation of gas station event; Awaijane family told to go inside gas station, they comply and seek shelter inside, police then shoot rubber bullets and tear gas inside the building
Medics talk about police destroying tent and slashing tires.
Officer pepper-sprays or maces protester walking backwards with arms raised
Officer pepper-sprays protester
Police remove badges
Police pepperspray protesters for chanting
Police pepper spray and arrest protester holding sign
Reporter is arrested and detained for 6 hours
Police pepper spray protesters; rip mask off protester
Police use tear gas on protesters
Police intimidating campus protesters by driving car towards them
desc: Police drive their car towards protesters in order to disperse them

title: Police tackle and detain 6 protesters
desc: Waterbury police detain at least 6 people at an assembly at the intersection of Wolcott St. and Long Hill Rd., apparently for blocking the road. Police had warned protesters several times that if they remained on Wolcott St., they would be arrested. Police tackle multiple protesters, including one (who one post claims is 15 years old) who is thrown to the ground and pinned down for an extended period, with one officer kneeling on him, in what appears to be excessive force. A dog is present, but apparently not used. Waterbury authorities say no property was damaged during the protest. Arrested protesters were not charged.

title: Police pepper spray young child
desc:
Police pepper sprays a young child who is seen crying, while protesters pour milk on the distressed girl.

Related to Seattle OPA Case 2020OPA-0322.

title: Police beat hospital employee walking home
desc: Rayne Valentine, a hospital employee in Brooklyn, states he was walking home on the night of the 31st after an overtime shift assisting with COVID-19 care. Valentine states he saw police chasing a teen and began recording. After a short interaction, police began beating Valentine. He states that police then threw his phone to him and left. Valentine then walked back to the hospital, where he received 2 CT scans and 7 staples.

title: Police kneel to lure protesters closer before firing
Police tear gas reporters
Police arrest hospital employee acting as medic
desc:
A crowd gathers around as a man in scrubs is arrested.

In a report after the fact, he says police laughed when he and other detained protesters requested masks. He also states that he was kept with 17 people in a small, warm room (he approximates 8'x10' and 85 degrees).

title: Sheriff arrests woman for sign containing profanity
desc: In a continuation of events from June 3rd (ga-valdosta-1), sheriff Ashley Paulk arrested a woman carrying a sign suggestive of a "lewd act" between Paulk and Donald Trump, fulfilling his threat to arrest protesters carrying signs containing profanity. He cited a Georgia law allowing misdemeanor charges for profanity in the presence of an individual under 14 years of age, despite [U.S. Supreme Court cases](https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=7398433541275578772&q=cohen+v.+california&hl=en&as_sdt=3,39) and [Georgia Supreme Court cases](https://law.justia.com/cases/georgia/supreme-court/2017/s17a1040.html) exonerating individuals charged with similar crimes.

title: Protesters detained more than 24 hours by police; upheld by NY Judge
desc:
The Legal Aid Society, a law firm for low-income families and individuals, filed an emergency lawsuit after learning protesters had been detained for over 24 hours without arraignment, in violation of New York state law.

A New York state judge rejected the appeal, allowing the NYPD to continue holding protesters, citing the virtual arraignments made necessary by the COVID-19 pandemic as a cause of slower processing. However, the Legal Aid Society states that conditions are not suitable for social distancing in the holding cells, thus risking an increased spread of COVID-19.

The NY Daily News cited that as of Thursday, June 4th, 202 people had been detained for over 24 hours.

title: Police shove member of the press
White-shirted officers shove protesters
Law enforcement officer fires tear gas at vehicle only to discover it's a police vehicle
Police arrest journalist Michael Harriot
Police abduct woman in unmarked van
Police break up neighborhood BBQ, beating and arresting partygoers
Police fire rubber bullets on dispersing crowd
desc:
After disperse order is given, protesters comply and begin to back away from the police line. Police fire rubber bullets at dispersing protesters and harrass woman (filmer) who has been shot in the leg and is unable to move quickly.

June 5th date determined by Reddit submitter stating video, which is stamped "1d ago", to have been uploaded on June 6th, 2020. Confirmed that mass protests did occurr in Hunstville on June 5th.

title: Protester targeted days after protest
desc:
Footage and reports show approximately 30 police officers in 6-7 squad cars arrive to arrest a woman in a car with her 9 year old child.

Officers arrived on the scene brandishing mace, alleging that the woman assaulted two police officers several days prior. She was dragged from her car and the car was towed from her home.

Officers cited a Star Wars meme depicting a Landspeeder with a caption saying, "This machine kills facists," as intent to kill officers.

The woman states she tried to help a friend who was being shot with rubber bullets.

title: Police shoot peaceful protesters on sidewalk
desc: Footage shows a police van drive up on a small group of protesters on the sidewalk, walking away from the officers. Police jump off the van and immediately begin firing at protesters.

title: Bronze star veteran recounts injuries from police at protests
Protester struck in head at short range with explosive projectile
Police drive up to protesters, jump out and tackle them
desc: Footage shows two police SUVs accelerating past the police line, knocking over a trash can in the process. They pull up next to protesters and jump out of the car. Police from the vehicles and on the street charge protesters, tackle them, and arrest them. Police appear to kneel on protesters while making arrests.

title: Officer attacks photographer with baton and pepper sprays him
desc: A police officer is seen advancing on a photographer, hitting him with his baton and pepper spraying him.

title: Police kettle protesters to force them to disperse through tear-gas
Police fire tear gas at fleeing protesters
Police pull departing protester from bike to arrest them
desc: Body cam footage from a police officer shows police approaching person on a bike, believed to be a protester leaving the protest. The two officers pull the protester from the bike to make an arrest, throwing the bike aside. An officer then tells passersby at a convenience store to go home.

title: Police arrest homeless man
Police violently arrest drummer
Police arrest people taking pictures, threaten to arrest press
Officer forces press away from protest
Police pepper spray protesters standing in their way
desc: Video shows several police officers attempting to make their way past the fence perimeter of the Capitol Hill Occupied Protest area, in order to gain access to the vacated precinct. Several protesters block their path on the sidewalk. The cops pepper spray at least one individual at close range. The person filming says "they're tear-gassing people!" but the video caption says "accidentally said 'tear gas' instead of 'pepper spray' in the video." The crowd shouts loudly until the officers retreat.

title: Police shove multiple reporters
desc: At protests on the night of June 4th, multiple reporters share footage of police shoving them with batons. One reporter states she was released from arrest after showing her press badge, but says she was shoved around first.

title: Law enforcement officer fires tear gas at vehicle only to discover it's a police vehicle
desc: In this video, an officer fires a tear gas canister at a slow moving vehicle. It appears that he was unaware the vehicle belonged to the police.

title: Police fire tear gas at peaceful protest
desc: Police fire tear gas at peaceful protesters, while simultaneously ordering protesters to lie down, forcing them to remain in the immediate area.

title: Police grab protester by the hair, shove her into car
desc: After a scuffle between protesters and police at Washington Ave and Fulton St in Brooklyn, a protester walking away is grabbed by the hair and thrown into the side of a police car. The officer shoves a second protester into the car as well.

title: Officer shoves protester
Couple arrested on their stoop for cheering protesters
One woman is pinned to the ground and another is pepper-sprayed
Police arrest hospital employee acting as medic
Protesters detained more than 24 hours by police; upheld by NY Judge
Tear gas fired at fleeing protesters & passing cars
desc: Footage from between 1 and 2 AM on June 5th shows police firing tear gas rounds at a group of protesters walking away from them. Several cars are stopped at traffic and/or passing through the intersection where canisters land.

title: Armed police raid gay bar helping wounded Black Lives Matter protesters on the first day of Pride Month
desc: "Des Moines police approached The Blazing Saddle, a gay bar in Des Moines East Village neighborhood, and searched the premises  apparently without a warrant. Video from a security camera made public on Facebook shows officers in riot gear converging suddenly on the bar at approximately 11:45 p.m. and detaining those gathered outside." - The Iowa Inquirer

title: Police fire projectiles at protesters and discharge teargas
Armed police raid gay bar helping wounded Black Lives Matter protesters on the first day of Pride Month
Police charge and arrest peaceful protesters
desc: A police contingent far outnumbering protesters shows up to block roads. Protesters are peaceful and the majority follow order to back away. Nonetheless, footage shows arrests and police charging at protesters.

title: Officer chokes and places knee on neck of woman
desc:
Video shows officer on back of woman laying face down. Officer has the woman in a choke hold. Officer then moves to place both
knees on back during arrest, one knee on middle of the back and the other behind the neck of the woman. Officer is reported to work for Bellevue Police Department. Arrest made over what twitter user @_SJPeace_ described as a title transfer.

title: Officer attacks photographer with baton and pepper sprays him
Police drive up to protesters, jump out and tackle them
Police arrest people taking pictures, threaten to arrest press
desc: Footage shows a squad car pulling up next to two individuals and a police officer on foot. One officer can be heard saying, "You were standing there taking photos," as he arrests the individuals. Another officer then shouts: "Leave the area or you will be arrested." The filmer states that he is press and the officer reiterates that he will be arrested if he remains.

title: Police beat protesters in park
desc: Footage shows protesters fleeing from tear gas or smoke in a park. Frames are captured that show protesters apparently struggling to breathe. Police can be seen ripping umbrellas from protesters and striking them.

title: Woman hit with police projectile resumes breathing after CPR, delivered to hospital
Officer forces press away from protest
desc:
A reporter with a press pass is told that his pass does not matter and press is not permitted at the scene. Later, a second officer states the same thing. After asking the second officer for his name, the officer lets the reporter film his badge number but does not give his name. After asking again, the officer threatens the journalist, saying: "Do you want to go to jail?" before grabbing the journalist and arresting them.

Reports on the Portland curfew state explicitly that media are exempt from curfew restrictions.

title: Police make violent arrests; arrest woman filming
desc:
The first two minutes of footage show police making a series of violent arrests: they throw protesters to the ground, strike them and kneel on them. At the end of the footage, an officer approaches the filmer, throws her to the ground, and arrests her.

Dover PD is investigating the use of force incident.

The protest began on Route 13 near the Delaware State Capitol before moving to an area near a WAWA in Camden, Delaware, where police and protesters clashed.

title: Police pepper spray protesters standing in their way
Police SUV pushes through protesters, knocks over protester on bike
desc:
In this video, protesters on bikes are shown blocking a police vehicle from progressing down a road. The vehicle moves around the protesters, but instead of continuing on the sidewalk until getting past the crowd, the cop pushes the car through the protesters and knocks a protester off of their bike.

The officer driving the vehicle has been cleared by the department of any wrongdoing.

title: Police charge protesters
Before firing tear gas, Salem PD warns white armed men
desc: A police officer is seen warning white armed men that police are planning to fire tear gas, and that they should find a safe, indoors location so that the PD does not appear to be playing favorites. The officer states that this warning comes at the request of his command.

title: NYPD pushes crowd into tight space and makes violent mass arrests
desc:
At roughly 8:00 PM, on E. 136th St. by Brook Ave, cops pushed protesters into an increasingly tight space and use pepper spray and batons. Police then proceeded to make violent mass arrests. Footage shows use of batons and shields to strike protesters and police kneeling on protesters to make arrests.

Footage additionally shows officers standing on cars to swing batons at protesters.

One video additionally shows protesters shouting for a medic as a woman has gone into labor.

title: White-shirted officers shove protesters
desc: Footage taken from a Periscope stream filmed at Washington Ave and Fulton St in Brooklyn shows a crowd of protesters marching. Two white-shirted officers push through the crowd, shoving protesters. An officer appears to grab a protester in a manner similar to a horse collar before releasing them and chasing after another protester.

title: NYPD target non-protesting legal observers
desc:
